<span class="style1">For more information on how you can stay on in the UK and work after
you complete your studies at Abertay please refer to the following links
<span class="style1">The Science and Engineering Graduates Scheme (SEGS) allows non-EEA nationals
who have graduated in physical sciences
subjects with a 2.2 or higher to remain in the UK for 12 months after
their studies in order to pursue a career. For more information: www.workingintheuk.gov.uk/
overseas students who have graduated from a Scottish university or
college to apply to stay in Scotland for up to two years after they
graduate to seek and take work.
Non-EEA students who have graduated with an HND
or a PhD from a Scottish University or college and who have lived
in Scotland while they were studying will be eligible to apply.
Fresh Talent Scheme is available on the website www.scotlandistheplace.com. Find out more about the Fresh Talent: Working in Scotland Scheme.

column2: and is also an important centre for international

column1: consultants who can assess your potential and introduce you to some
of the most successful multinational businesses in the world.
You should also talk to people in your academic department. Your lecturer
tutor or research supervisor may know of organisations (in the UK or
overseas) that offer work programmes related to your studies.
You can find information about work permits here: www.ind.homeoffice.gov.uk.
<span class="style1">Leaving will be just as hard as arriving. There will be many things
you have to organise well in advance and people you will want to stay
in contact with. You may even feel that you have lost contact with your
family and friends at home so be prepared to face the culture shock
all over again. Your time in Scotland will have undoubtedly had a positive
impact on you so saying goodbye might be harder than you first expect.
Give yourself time to adjust and reacclimatize. Don't forget you have
just completed not only an academic journey but a personal one too.
Talk to the student international advisor and the academic staff you
have felt most comfortable with - they will be interested to know your

column2: and they might even be able to help you with some of the arrangements
